page.title: 12THE NAME " ABERFELDY "
page.content: There are two legends. The first concerns a bishop named {Palladius}who came from Ireland in AD469. He set up home near the{Moness {Burn}in what became known as 'the field of the church'. The{Gaelic}word for Palladius is {PEALLAIDH}and the old name for the burn came from this-the{'paldy'}or {'faldy'. {'Aber'}means 'at,or near,the{mouth of {a burn'}so Aberfeldy means 'near the mouth of a burn'. The second concerns a water sprite, an{Urisk}named{Paellaidh an Spuit, who lived at the{Upper Falls of Moness from where he would come to the town during harvest time to lend a hand. Small offering were taken as payment to this kindly character but if treated disrespectfully,he would become very mischievous.
